images.summary: This image is a West Elevation of a building, as indicated by the title 'WEST ELEVATION' and the sheet reference 'S1'. The scale is provided as 1/8" = 1'-0". The elevation shows the building's exterior features, including a metal roof with cupolas, vertical metal siding, and a concrete foundation line at the base. Key openings include a large section labeled '136'-0" x 10'-0" HIGH CURTAINS' which appears to be a large opening or a series of openings for curtains, and a '20'-0" X 10'-6" O/H DOOR' (Overhead Door). There are also smaller window openings depicted. Dimensions are provided for the overhead door and the curtain opening, as well as distances from the edge to specific features, such as '-8'-0"' and '-5'-8"' which likely denote offsets or dimensions to openings or structural elements. The term 'CONC.' indicates a concrete foundation or base element visible at the bottom of the elevation.

This image is an elevation view of a building's exterior. It depicts metal roofing and metal siding. The elevation shows several openings, including windows and large "104'-0" x 10'-0" HIGH CURTAINS", which likely represent large garage doors or similar openings. Dimensions such as 7'-0" and 11'-0" are shown, indicating spacing between elements or openings. A concrete foundation is visible at the base of the wall, with a label "CONC." indicating concrete. The overall height of the building is not explicitly stated but implied by the scale and annotations. The title "EVATION" suggests this is an elevation drawing, and the scale "= 1'-0" indicates that one unit on the drawing represents one foot.

This image contains notes detailing two types of shearwalls: SINGLE SHEARWALL and DOUBLE SHEARWALL. The SINGLE SHEARWALL utilizes 7/16" OSB on one side, fastened with 2 3/8" nail-gun nails spaced at 4" on center along panel edges and 8" on center in the field. Blocking is specified at 24" on center and along all panel edges. Each end of the shearwall panel requires a (3) ply stud post, unless a post is already present. The DOUBLE SHEARWALL is similar but has 7/16" OSB on both sides, with the same nailing schedule for panel edges and field, and the same blocking and stud post requirements. Both details reference "DETAIL 2/S3" for further information. The visual elements include schematic representations of the shearwall construction, with one showing a single layer of OSB and the other showing double layers, and the associated fastening and blocking details.

images.summary: This document appears to be a schedule or a collection of details related to foundation walls, baseplates, and footings. It defines various types of foundation walls, including an 8" foundation wall (W1) that is 4'-4" high, a 10" sandwich foundation wall (W2) that is 8'-0" high, and several types of curb walls (W3, W3b, W4, W6) with heights ranging from 1'-0" to 4'-0". All walls are specified as 25 MPa concrete and require reinforcement as per referenced details (e.g., W1 requires reinforcement per Detail 7/S6). A 24" wide x 8" footing with 20 MPa concrete and (2) 15M continuous reinforcement is also noted. The Baseplate Schedule lists two types: BP1, a 12"x12"x3/4" thick baseplate with (4) 3/4" diameter x 8" anchor bolts, and BP2, an off-set 6"x12"x3/4" thick baseplate with (2) 3/4" diameter x 8" anchor bolts, both referencing Detail 2/S6. The Footing Schedule details two footing types: F1, a 5'-6"x5'-6"x14" thick concrete footing with 20 MPa concrete and (5) 15M reinforcing bars each way, and F2, a 4'-0"x4'-0"x12" thick concrete footing with 20 MPa concrete and (4) 15M reinforcing bars each way. Both footings are to be poured on undisturbed soil and reference specific details for further information. The "GRADE" and "SPECS" labels suggest this is part of a larger set of construction documents.

images.summary: This detail illustrates a 12" high curb wall, referencing sheet S2. The curb itself is described as being 8" or 6" thick poured concrete, with its height determined by owner direction. A vertical reinforcement of 15M bars is specified, matching the curb height and extending 10" high, with hooks spaced at 24" on center in alternating directions, embedded into a thickened floor section. The main concrete floor is 6" thick, resting on compacted granular 'A' fill. Below the curb, the floor is thickened to 8" over a 24" width and includes continuous (2) 15M reinforcement. The detail also indicates a wall or penning element above the curb, as per plan, with (2) 15M horizontal bars at the top of the curb. The scale of the drawing is 3/4" = 1'-0".

A note indicates '(2) 15M CONT' which likely refers to continuous reinforcement within the floor slab or foundation, and a 1'-8" dimension is shown for the base width of the curb assembly. images.location: Ground Floor – Manure storage area and adjacent barn sections
images.element_type: Manure Storage Pad and Foundation Plan
images.summary: This plan view depicts the ground floor layout, focusing on a manure storage pad and adjacent barn foundation walls. The manure storage area is a 3200 sq.ft. pad with a 6" thick concrete floor, specified as 32 MPA concrete reinforced with 6x6x6/6 W.W.M. centered in the slab, laid over a minimum of 6" of compacted Granular 'A' fill on undisturbed soil. A critical note advises against bonding the manure storage floor to the barn foundation or barn floor. The plan also shows various foundation walls (W1, W2, W3, W4, W6) and footings (F1, F2) with associated reinforcement details and dimensions. For example, W1 is an 8" thick foundation wall 4'-4" high, reinforced as per detail 7/S6, and W2 is a 10" sandwich foundation wall 8'-0" high. Several details are referenced, including 'THICKENED FLOOR EDGE DETAIL 3/S3', 'MANGER CURB DETAIL 2/S2', '4'-0" HIGH CURB WALL DETAIL 3/S2', and '12" HIGH CURB WALL DETAIL 4/S2', indicating specific construction methods for edges and curbs. The plan also includes dimensions for various sections and bays, such as 12'-0" and 8'-0" spacing for elements, and overall dimensions like 67'-01/2" and 188'-0". The presence of 'UNEXCAVATED' areas suggests portions of the site are not yet prepared. Notes regarding run-off flow paths and the potential for differential movement due to frost/thaw are also present, emphasizing contractor/owner responsibility for any resulting cracks or heave if the slab is not constructed below frost level.

images.summary: This is a Foundation Plan view showing the layout of foundation elements for the main building structure. The plan details the "UNEXCAVATED" areas with a "6" CONCRETE FLOOR" constructed of "32 MPA POURED CONCRETE" over a "MIN 6" COMPACTED GRANULAR 'A' FILL" on "UNDISTURBED SOIL". Various foundation walls are indicated by callouts like "W1" (8" Foundation Wall, 4'-4" high, 25 MPA concrete), "W3" (8" Curb Wall, 1'-0" high, 25 MPA concrete), and "W4" (4" Curb/Manger Wall, 25 MPA concrete), with reinforcement specified as per associated details. Footings are identified by "F1" (5'-6" x 5'-6" x 14" thick concrete, 20 MPa pour) and "F2" (4'-0" x 4'-0" x 12" thick concrete, 20 MPa pour). The plan also shows "DROPPED PEN FLOOR" areas, referencing "EDGE DETAIL 2/S2" for specific construction. Several "CURB WALL DETAILS" are shown, including a "4'-0" HIGH CURB WALL DETAIL" (3/S2) and a "12" HIGH CURB WALL DETAIL" (4/S2), specifying concrete thickness, reinforcement (e.g., "15M HORIZ. @ 24" o.c.", "15M - VERT. MATCH CURB HEIGHT x 12" H."), and connection to thickened floor sections. "Baseplate Schedule" entries like "BP1" (12" x 12" x 3/4" thick baseplate with 3/4" anchor bolts) are also noted. Section callouts like "1/S5", "2/S5", "3/S2", and "4/S2" link this plan to other relevant drawings. The legend clarifies symbols for "TOP OF WALL" (212) and "FLOOR HEIGHT" (200).

images.summary: This detail illustrates the edge of a manure pad, providing specific construction requirements. The concrete element has a total height of 10 inches, with a 3-inch concrete cover specified for the bottom and sides, and 2-inch cover for the top. The concrete is reinforced with four continuous 15M bars, requiring a minimum lap splice of 1 foot 8 inches. The pad slopes away, indicated by an arrow and text annotation. The foundation beneath the concrete consists of a minimum of 6 inches of compacted granular fill, designated as 'A'. A beveled edge is shown with a slope of 1 on 2. The detail is titled 'MANURE PAD EDGE DETAIL' and is referenced as detail 3 on sheet S3, with a scale of 3/4" = 1'-0".

images.location: Shearwall anchor connection to foundation wall
images.summary: This detail illustrates the connection between a shearwall and a concrete foundation wall, identified as 'SHEARWALL ANCHOR DETAILS' on sheet S3. The detail shows a side view of the connection. The shearwall is constructed with 7/16" OSB sheathing on one or two sides, fastened with 2 3/8" nail-gun nails at 4" on center along panel edges and 8" on center in the field. Blocking is provided at 24" on center and along all panel edges. The top of the wall is secured to a truss as per the roof plan. A 3-ply stud post is specified at each end of the wall section. The shearwall is anchored to the concrete foundation wall using a 6" x 3" x 1/4" angle, which is secured with a 5/8" anchor bolt or equivalent epoxy anchor with an 8" embedment into the concrete. This anchor detail is applied at each end of the shearwall. The foundation wall is a concrete foundation wall as per the plan. The anchor bolts are 1/2" diameter and spaced at 48" on center, indicated as typical. The detail includes a scale of 1" = 1'-0".

The foundation wall itself has a total width of 8 inches, with 4-inch dimensions shown for its base.

The plan depicts a large barn structure with various zones including "BILLY PENS", "GOAT PENS", "MANGER ALLEY", "UTILITY", "VET RM", "OFFICE", "PARLOUR", "NURSERY", and "BILLY KIDS". The overall dimensions of the structure are extensive, with a total length of 188'-0" and a width of approximately 123'-0". The plan shows a grid system with labels such as L1, L2, L3, L4, L5, and C1, C3, C4, C7, which define the layout and spacing of structural elements. Several steel beams are noted, including "W18 x 45 STEEL BEAM" spanning 26'-0" in multiple locations, and "W10" beams. Numerous "12'-0" X 11'-6" O/H DOOR" (Overhead Doors) are indicated along the perimeter, along with a "LIFT DOOR" and a "104'-0" x 10'-0" CURTAIN" wall. The plan also references section cuts with callouts like "1/S3", "2/S5", and "1/S5", which connect this plan to other drawings in the set. A detail at the bottom right shows a "3-PLY STUD POST" connection with "6" x 3" x 1/4" ANGLE C/W 5/8" ANCHOR BOLT" for shearwall applications, and a "POURED CONC. REINF. PER PLAN" detail with "4 - 15M CONTINUOUS MIN. 1'-8" LAP @ SPLICES" for concrete reinforcement, indicating a poured concrete slab with specific rebar requirements. The detail also shows "2" COVER TO CONC. (TOP & SIDES)" and "3" COVER TO CONC.", along with "COMPACTED GRAN. 'A' 6" MIN." for the sub-base preparation. The "SLOPE AWAY" annotation indicates drainage considerations for the concrete slab.

images.location: Foundation to Roof connection - Shearwall anchor details
images.summary: This detail illustrates the connection of shearwalls to the foundation and roof structure. The detail shows a side view and a section view of the shearwall anchor assembly. The shearwall is constructed with 7/16" O.S.B. sheathing on one or two sides, fastened with 2 3/8" nail-gun nails at 4" on center along panel edges and 8" on center in the field. Blocking is provided at 24" on center and along all panel edges. The top of the wall is secured to the truss as indicated on the roof plan. At each end of the shearwall, a 3-ply stud post is present. The connection to the foundation involves a 6" x 3" x 1/4" angle with a 5/8" anchor bolt or equivalent epoxy anchor, requiring 8" embedment into the concrete. The concrete foundation wall is 8" thick, and a 15M rebar perimeter is specified as typical. The section view further clarifies the assembly, showing the 8" concrete foundation wall and the 7/16" O.S.B. sheathing. The angle connector is fastened to the studs using eight 5/16" x 3" wood lags. The detail also shows 1/2" diameter anchor bolts spaced at 48" on center, typical for securing the wall to the foundation.

images.element_type: Wall, Lintel, and Column Schedules and Details
images.summary: This document page contains detailed specifications for framed walls, a lintel schedule, and a column schedule, likely serving as a reference for structural elements. The 'FRAMED WALLS' section defines multiple wall types, including W10 (2x6 Exterior Wall) with 29 ga. metal cladding, housewrap, 7/16" OSB sheathing secured with 2 3/8" nailgun nails at 6" o.c. on panel edges and 10" o.c. in the field, 2x6 studs at 24" o.c., R-20 batt insulation, and S-6 mil poly. Other framed walls like W11 (2x6 Interior Bearing Wall), W12 (2x6 Interior Wall), and W13 (2x4 Interior Partition Wall) are also detailed with varying stud spacing, insulation, and sheathing requirements. Specific shearwall details are provided: 'SINGLE SHEARWALL' uses 7/16" OSB on one side fastened with 2 3/8" nail-gun nails at 4" o.c. on panel edges and 8" o.c. in the field, with blocking at 24" o.c. and at all panel edges, and a (3) ply stud post at each end, referencing detail 2/S3. 'DOUBLE SHEARWALL' specifies 7/16" OSB on both sides with similar fastening and blocking, also referencing detail 2/S3. The 'LINTEL SCHEDULE' lists various lintel types (L1 through L6), including wood (LVL, 2x12 plates, 2x10 headers, 2x6 headers) and a W10 x 22 steel beam, with specific bearing and stud requirements and references to details on sheet S6. The 'COLUMN SCHEDULE' defines column types C1 (6x8 SPF #2 or better post), C3 (5" x 5" x 3/8" HSS steel post), and C4 (5" x 5" x 1/4" HSS steel post), all referencing details on sheet S6. This information is crucial for understanding the construction of walls, openings, and vertical supports within the building structure.

images.summary: This document section details various framed wall assemblies and shearwall construction. It defines specific wall types, identified by callouts such as W10, W11, W12, and W13, and outlines their material compositions and fastening schedules. For instance, W10 represents a 2x6 exterior wall featuring 29-gauge metal cladding over housewrap, 1x4 strapping at 24" on center, and 7/16" OSB sheathing secured with 2 3/8" nailgun nails at 6" on center at panel edges and 10" on center in the field. This wall also includes 2x6 studs at 24" on center, blocking at 48" on center, R-20 batt insulation, a 6-mil polyethylene vapor barrier, and an "AG TUFF LINER" as specified by the client. W11 is a 2x6 interior bearing wall with similar sheathing and fastening but with studs at 16" on center. W12 is a 2x6 interior wall with R-20 insulation and W13 is a 2x4 interior partition wall with R-12 insulation. The document also details "SINGLE SHEARWALL" and "DOUBLE SHEARWALL" construction. The single shearwall uses 7/16" OSB on one side, fastened with 2 3/8" nail-gun nails at 4" on center at panel edges and 8" on center in the field, with blocking at 24" on center and at all panel edges, and a (3) ply stud post at each end. The double shearwall has OSB on both sides with similar fastening and blocking requirements. Both shearwall types reference "DETAIL 2/S3" for further clarification. The use of "AG TUFF LINER AS PER CLIENT" is a recurring note across multiple wall types, indicating a specific finish or liner material requirement.

images.summary: This document contains notes and a legend for a roof plan. The legend defines symbols for bearing walls (dashed red line), fire stops (solid red line), pre-engineered trusses (dashed gray line), and continuous purlins (dashed blue line), referencing detail 3/S4 for purlin information. The roof plan notes provide critical construction guidance: attic fire stops are to be installed as shown, secured with 7/16" OSB to trusses or 2x3 framing, ensuring continuous support at all joints. A key dimensional constraint is that no single compartment dimension shall exceed 98'-4", and fire stops must not impede roof ventilation. The notes also specify requirements for attic hatches, stating that each attic portion needs one, or a single hatch and door can be used in the fire stops. Trusses are to bear directly onto posts, and all dimensions must be confirmed before ordering trusses. Additionally, "X" bracing for truss laterals is required as per manufacturer shop drawings reviewed by the project engineer, with specific guidance found in detail 1/S6. Overhangs are to be installed as dimensioned on the plan. The overall system involves pre-engineered trusses supported by posts, with specific fire stopping and bracing requirements detailed.

images.summary: This is a roof framing plan showing the layout of pre-engineered scissor trusses and associated framing members. The overall dimensions of the roof area are indicated as 69'-2" by approximately 108'-0". The primary structural elements are pre-engineered scissor trusses spaced at 48 inches on center (48" O.C.). These trusses are noted to bear directly to every other post. Blocking, specifically 2x10 blocking, is shown to be used for minimum span support. The plan also details the continuous purlin system along the ridge and eaves, with metal track specified to be centered over purlin splices. A critical detail is the requirement to make adjacent ridge and eave sections continuous by providing 4'-0" of 26ga track at each splice location, fastened with (16) N10HDG 1½" nails on each side of each splice, as referenced in (2/S4). Fire stops are indicated throughout the roof assembly and are to extend fully into soffits. Chimney vents are also shown, to be installed per ventilation design by others. The plan includes section callouts '1/S5' and '2/S5', indicating connections to other drawing sheets for further detail. The legend clarifies symbols for bearing walls, fire stops, pre-engineered trusses, and continuous purlins. Roof plan notes provide additional specifications regarding attic fire stops, attic hatches, truss bearing, and lateral bracing requirements for trusses, referencing detail 1/S6 for 'X' bracing.

images.summary: This is a roof framing plan view showing the layout of pre-engineered scissor trusses and rafters. The overall dimensions of the roof area are indicated, with a main span of 108'-0" and a width of 66'-5½". The pre-engineered scissor trusses are spaced at 48" on center and are designed to bear directly to every other post. Rafters are shown as 2x12 members at 24" on center, with 2x10 blocking at a minimum span. The plan details specific connections and continuity requirements for ridge and eave elements. For instance, it specifies making adjacent eave sections continuous by providing 4'-0" of 26ga track at each splice location, secured with (16) N10HDG 1½" nails on each side of each splice, as referenced in detail (2/S4). Similarly, adjacent ridge and eave sections are to be made continuous using the same track and nailing method. Firestop details are also indicated, with instructions to extend them fully into soffits. Chimney vents are noted as per ventilation design by others. Stitch screws at 12" on center are specified for connections, and a scale of 1/8" = 1'-0" is provided.

images.summary: This detail illustrates the construction of a milking parlour, focusing on the foundation and floor systems. The detail shows a 6-inch thick poured concrete wall with a height of 3'-4" above the floor, reinforced with 3-15M horizontal bars at 16" on center and 15M vertical bars at 16" on center, with the vertical bars bent 12" into the footing and top. The concrete strength specified is 32 MPa. The foundation includes a 15M rebar reinforcement at 18" on center in both directions, supporting the wall and floor. The floor itself is a 6" thick concrete slab, also 32 MPa, with a crown for drainage. A portion of the floor is a 6" thick suspended slab, 2'-6" wide, designed as a tunnel for a milk pump, reinforced with 15M bars at 12" on center each way, with a specified concrete cover of 1 1/2" from the bottom of the slab to the first layer of rebar. The detail also shows a sill plate assembly with 1/2" anchor bolts at 48" on center, secured on a 1/4" sill gasket. Backfill with granular fill is indicated to a depth of 2'-6" below the slab. The detail is referenced as "MILKING PARLOUR DETAIL" and is shown at a scale of 3/4" = 1'-0", with a callout of 3/S5, indicating it is detail 3 on sheet S5.

images.summary: This detail illustrates the construction of a milk pump pit, which is a foundation element. The pit features an 8-inch thick concrete wall constructed with 32 MPa concrete. This wall is reinforced with 15M horizontal rebar spaced at 16 inches on center and 15M vertical rebar, also at 16 inches on center, with a 12-inch hook extending into the footing. The footing itself, which also serves as the pit floor, is 8 inches thick and made of 32 MPa poured concrete. It is reinforced with 15M rebar at 18 inches on center in both directions and is designed to bear on native soil with a capacity of 3000 psf. The detail highlights a tunnel opening in the wall beyond the pit and specifies thickened edges of the surrounding floor to 8 inches. Reinforcement around openings includes (2) 15M vertical bars beside the opening and (2) 15M horizontal bars above the opening, extending 12 inches past its edge, with 24-inch by 15M diagonal bars at the corners. Additionally, 15M by 30-inch long bars are specified as dowels into the foundation wall at 24 inches on center, requiring a 4-inch embedment using HIT-HY 200 adhesive or similar. A minimum of 2 inches of concrete cover is indicated for the reinforcement. The detail is referenced as 'MILK PUMP PIT DETAIL' on sheet S5, with a scale of 3/4" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This drawing contains two section views of a barn and milking area. The first section, labeled 'SECTION THRU BARN S5', shows a typical barn wall assembly resting on a foundation wall and footing. Key components include a sill plate with 1/2" anchor bolts at 48" on center, a double top plate, and wall construction per plan. The roof structure features mono trusses with top chord bearing and continuous diagonal bracing on vertical truss members. Additional cellulose insulation is noted to suit beside the wall. The second section, 'SECTION THRU MILKING AREA S5', details the milking parlour area. It illustrates pre-engineered scissor trusses spaced at 48" on center, with 2x4 strapping at 24" on center and 2x4 lateral bracing. The roof cladding is 29ga metal. The section also specifies R40 loosefill insulation and an S6ml poly vapour barrier. Details for continuous ridge and eave track splices are provided, requiring 4'-0" 26ga track with (16) N10HDG 1½" nails on each side of each splice. "X" bracing of truss laterals is required as per manufacturer shop drawings, reviewed by the project engineer, and referenced to Detail 1/S6. Uplift clips are specified as per truss drawings at each bearing location. The foundation includes a concrete slab per plan, bearing on a foundation wall and footing. Vertical dimensions are provided, such as the wall height of 13'-4 7/8" for the barn section and 10'-2 3/4" for the milking area wall. The drawing also indicates a pit per Detail 4/S5 and vented soffits.

images.summary: This section view illustrates a cross-section through a barn, detailing the roof structure, walls, and foundation. The roof system features pre-engineered scissor trusses spaced at 48 inches on center, supporting 29ga metal roof cladding and 2x4 strapping at 24 inches on center. Lateral bracing is specified as required, with "X" bracing of truss laterals detailed as per manufacturer shop drawings, reviewed by the project engineer, and referenced as "SEE DETAIL 1/S6". Uplift clips are to be provided at each bearing location as per truss drawings. The roof assembly includes R40 loosefill insulation and an S6ml poly vapour barrier. Ridge and eave connections are continuous, requiring 4'-0" of 26ga track with (16) N10HDG 1½" nails on each side of each splice, as noted with callout "(2/S4)". The wall structure consists of bearing walls and exterior posts, with foundation walls and footings as per plan. A concrete slab is present, with its thickness and details to be confirmed per plan. The overall height of the structure is indicated as 22'-6" from the foundation to the peak. Various blocking elements (2x10, 2x8, 2x6 strut) and venting details (roof venting, morvents, vented soffits) are shown. The foundation includes a footing, foundation wall, and backfill with parent material. The scale of the drawing is 3/16" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This detail illustrates the connection between a structural post and a foundation wall, including the roof truss bearing and plate assembly. The finished overhang of the roof structure extends 4'-0". It specifies that every other truss bears directly onto the post, while trusses located between posts are secured to an uplift scab using 10-3 1/2" nails or Simpson uplift clips. Two plate configurations are detailed: L1 involves a level plate let into the post, and L2 describes a hang plate positioned against the post, secured with (8) spikes. An additional L1 scab, 12" long and fastened with (6) spikes, is also shown. The post's exterior face is flush with the exterior of the concrete foundation wall on the curtain side. A Simpson Strong-Tie post bracket, model CBQGT66-SDS2 (galvanized), is used to connect the post to the foundation. The detail is referenced as '5/S6' and is drawn at a scale of 1/2" = 1'-0".

images.element_type: Steel Beam to Stud Post Connection Detail
images.summary: This detail illustrates the connection between a steel beam and a stud post, likely for framing an opening such as a door. The detail shows a steel beam bearing on a stud post, which is anchored to a concrete foundation wall. The connection involves a 3/8" endplate secured to the steel beam and the stud post with (#) 1/2" diameter A325 bolts. A table indicates the number of bolts required based on the size of the steel beams (W24 beams require 12 bolts, W21 beams require 10, W16-W18 beams require 8, and W12-W14 beams require 6, W8-W10 beams require 4). The stud posts are specified as full length and bearing per plan. A pre-engineered truss is shown bearing on the steel beam, with truss clips per plan. A double top plate is secured to the studs with sheathing per plan. Another detail, (2) plates secured to the beam with 1/2" bolts @ 24" on center (staggered sides of flange), is also noted, matching wall top plate or beam width or truss manufacturer requirements. The opening is framed down to the desired door height and sheathed with plywood. The stud post is anchored to the foundation wall, with a reference to 'SEE DETAIL 2/S3' for the foundation anchor detail. The scale of the drawing is 1/2" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This detail illustrates a "Sandwich Fnd. Wall Detail" (S6) for a foundation wall. The primary structural element is a 10" thick concrete sandwich wall constructed with 25 MPa poured concrete. This wall incorporates 2" thick rigid insulation and is reinforced with 10M rebar placed horizontally on each side at 16" on center and vertically at 24" on center. A minimum of 1 1/2" concrete coverage is specified for all reinforcing bars. The detail also shows a 24" wide by 8" thick footing made of 20 MPa concrete, containing two runs of 15M rebar, which bears on undisturbed soil. The footing is connected to the wall via 15M x 24" dowels spaced at 24" on center, or alternatively, two 10M x 24" dowels at the same spacing, both requiring a minimum 6" embedment into the footing. Anchor bolts are specified: 1/2" anchor bolts welded to U-hook bars at 4'-0" on center are shown connecting to the top of the wall, and 1/2" anchor bolts welded to a "U" at 48" on center are shown connecting to the stud per plan. The detail indicates that insulation should be kept 24" back from the face of wall openings, as is typical unless otherwise noted (TYP. U.N.O.). The overall height of the wall shown in the detail is 8'-0", with various 1'-4" increments indicated. A separate detail labeled "LT DETAIL" shows a 1/2" anchor bolt welded to a U-hook bar at 4'-0" o.c. The footing is dimensioned at 2'-0" wide. The scale of the drawing is 1/2" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This detail illustrates the installation of lateral X bracing for roof trusses, specifically focusing on the connection and bracing members. The detail shows 2x4 lumber used for diagonal bracing and struts. Key annotations indicate that the spacing of the diagonal bracing is as specified by the bracing designer, with a maximum span of 48'-0". Struts are specified as 2x4 lumber, 5'-0" long, attached to the top and bottom chords with two 3 1/2" nails at each truss web member. Diagonal braces are anchored to laterals with four 3 1/2" nails at the intersection of the truss web and truss lateral. Diagonal "X" bracing is to be installed on the opposite side of the truss at endwalls and where specified. Connections for diagonal "X" bracing on the opposite side of the web require two 3 1/2" nails at each truss. Butt joints for 2x4 laterals at splice locations must be tight and centered on the truss web. Lap joints for diagonal bracing are to span a minimum of 2 trusses to ensure complete coverage from top chord to bottom chord. The detail also references strapping or sheathing on the roof deck, spaced as specified by the truss engineer, and notes that 2x4 lumber is used for this purpose. The scale of the detail is 3/16" = 1'-0".

images.element_type: Steel Beam to Steel Column Connection Details
images.summary: This detail drawing illustrates various connection types between steel beams and steel columns, as well as steel posts. It shows different configurations for beam-to-column connections, including the use of top plates, end plates, and bolted connections. For instance, one detail shows a 1/2" thick top plate with (4) 3/4" A325 bolts connecting to the beam flange. Another detail depicts double top plates bolted to a steel beam with 1/2" diameter bolts at 24" on center, staggered. The drawing also specifies the number of 3/4" A325 bolts required for connecting beams of different sizes, such as W24 beams requiring 12 bolts and W8-W10 beams requiring 4 bolts. Connections to HSS steel columns are shown with base plates and anchor bolts. Detail BP1 illustrates an HSS steel post connection with a 3/4" thick galvanized base plate secured by (4) 1/2" anchor bolts, each 1'-0" long. Detail BP2 shows a base plate connection for a steel column, featuring a 6" x 12" x 3/4" base plate with (2) 3/4" x 8" long anchor bolts. The foundation detail includes a 12" x 12" x 3/4" base plate with (4) 3/4" diameter x 8" anchor bolts, resting on compacted granular fill, with a minimum depth of 2'-0" specified. Reinforcement for the foundation is indicated as 15M in each direction, as per the footing schedule. Web stiffeners, 3/8" thick, are specified on each side of the web directly above the column for through beams. Typical connection details, such as 1/4" fillet welds and 3/4" A325 bolts, are noted throughout the drawing.

The anchor bolt extends through a steel plate or bracket, with dimensions indicating a 4 1/2" projection above the bracket and 1 1/2" below. The U-hook bar, which is welded to the anchor bolt, is spaced at 4'-0" on center. The concrete element has a width of 10" and a visible height of 6". The detail clearly shows the embedment of the U-hook bar within the concrete, providing a secure anchor point. This type of detail is critical for connecting structural steel elements, such as columns or base plates, to concrete foundations or walls.
